content.webTitle: Five things you didn't know about Nordsjaelland

fields.headline: Five things you didn't know about Nordsjaelland
fields.bodyText: The club was founded on 1 January 1991 under the name Farum Boldklub, a merger of Farum Idraetsklub and Stavnsholt FC, and began life in the seventh tier of Danish football. They became FC Nordsjaelland in 2003 after a local businessman, Allan Pedersen, took the club over from the former owner Peter Brixtofte. The Danish champions boast a Laudrup in their ranks – Andreas Laudrup, Michael's youngest son. The 21-year-old is an attacking midfielder who joined Nordsjaelland in 2009. Nordsjaelland's match against Chelsea will take place at Parken Stadium, the home of FC Copenhagen. The venue holds 38,000 people, which is 18,000 more than the entire population of Farum, the town where the club are based. Long-standing immigration has made Farum a diverse town; over 50 different languages are spoken there, with the majority of the immigrant population being Turkish. Nordsjaelland's nickname is the "Wild Tigers" and to help maintain the theme the club's principal colours are red and orange.
